Exercise

The Cartesian coordinates of \(P\), \(Q\) are \(({@rand_x_P@}, {@rand_y_P@})\) and \(({@rand_x_Q@} ,{@rand_y_Q@})\). What are their equivalent polar coordinates? Please leave your answers in exact form, you may write \(\arctan(x)\) as atan(x) and \(\sqrt{x}\) as sqrt(x).

generalfeedback.text:
From the key point, we know that \(r = +\sqrt{x^2+y^2}\) and \(\theta = \arctan\dfrac{y}{x}\). Substituting in the values from the question, we get that the Cartesian coordinates \(\left({@rand_x_P@},\ {@rand_y_P@}\right)\) correspond to the Polar coordinates \(\left(+\sqrt{({@rand_x_P@})^2 + ({@rand_y_P@})^2},\ \arctan\left(\dfrac{{@rand_y_P@}}{{@rand_x_P@}}\right)\right) = \left({@taPr@}, {@taPtheta@}\right)\), and the Cartesian coordinates\(\left({@rand_x_Q@},\ {@rand_y_Q@}\right)\) correspond to the Polar coordinates \(\left(+\sqrt{({@rand_x_Q@})^2 + ({@rand_y_Q@})^2},\ \arctan\left(\dfrac{{@rand_y_Q@}}{{@rand_x_Q@}}\right)\right) = \left({@taQr@}, {@taQtheta@}\right)\). See the graph below for a visual representation of this (Note if the text is stacked on top of one another, they can be dragged apart using the mouse):
